physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. It features large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds. The left panel presents the bouquet on a dark blue background filled with floral tendrils as a secondary motif. The panel on the right presents the bouquet pattern against a light cream background with leaf-like patterns as a secondary motif.
sgcool_label_text: The buketan design, comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds, is shown on this sarong.  The same rose bouquet is repeated on both the kepala (broad vertical panel) and badan (‘body’ or main design field) of this batik.  Although the buketan design remains the same, the creative use of background patterns for both the motifs itself and on the background, results in a lively overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.
